Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Dynamics and Impacts of Fine-Scale Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will test the hypothesis that fine-scale processes regulate the response of climate to elevated greenhouse forcing at the spatial and temporal scales that matter most for climate change impacts. In order to test this hypothesis, the investigators will establish an approach to climate change uncertainty quantification that uses a suite of impacts metrics as indicators of the magnitude and spatial heterogeneity of physical climate change. This approach will require a combination of existing and new climate model experiments; climate model configuration and testing; observational data analysis; and climate change impacts analysis. This over-arching hypothesis will be tested by systematically testing sub-hypotheses relating fine-scale climate processes to (1) the level of greenhouse forcing, (2) the response of large-scale climate processes, and (3) the internal climate system variability.

The investigators will produce a suite of high-resolution climate model experiments and impacts analyses. These experiments and analyses will contribute to a systematic, quantitative evaluation of the importance of fine-scale climate processes relative to other sources of climate change uncertainty, as well as a quantitative assessment of the potential impacts of elevated greenhouse gas concentrations on a suite of impacts indicators. Although this impacts-based approach will have the secondary benefit of generating climate change impacts assessments (including for severe heat, severe precipitation, and snowmelt), the primary benefit will be to better identify, understand and compare key physical processes that govern the response of the climate system to elevated greenhouse forcing.

The project will have a number of tangible broader impacts, including the design, development, and assessment of a framework for the Stanford University Learning About Climate Change web-resource. The investigators will also seek to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups through graduate student recruiting efforts. Further, the results of this project are likely to result in tangible benefits to society, particularly given the current need for improved scientific understanding and communication that inform local, state, national, and international climate policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has focused on the physical processes that shape high-impact climate variability and change. The research has generated results that fall in four broad areas:

• The climate dynamics shaping high-impact regional climate change: One approach to identifying the physical dynamics that are likely to shape future climate impacts is to investigate the phenomena that create stress in the current climate. For example, severe heat is one of the most direct and far-reaching sources of climate-related stress. Our work was the first to show that global warming is likely to cause permanent emergence of novel heat regimes, and that such emergence is already detectable in observations. Likewise, despite the acute disasters caused by severe thunderstorms, their response to global warming has been one of the most prominent uncertainties in assessing extreme events. Our analyses of the daily atmospheric conditions in a large suite of climate models showed that increases in the energy available for atmospheric convection overwhelm decreases in wind shear to cause robust increases in the occurrence of severe thunderstorm environments. Similarly, African Easterly Waves (“AEWs”) are important for precipitation over the drought-vulnerable Sahel region, and for the genesis of Atlantic hurricanes. We showed that changes in regional temperature gradients are likely to increase the occurrence of strong AEWs. Further, stagnant air masses contribute to poor air quality episodes. We showed that continued global warming is likely to increase the occurrence of air stagnation events over large mid-latitude areas, increasing risk of pollution exposure for large urban populations. Together, these studies illustrate that the impacts of global warming are regulated by changes in regional climate dynamics that generate high-impact climate events.

• Historical global warming, climate dynamics, and climate change impacts: In collaboration with statisticians, economists and biologists, we have used historical data to investigate the physical processes by which climate influences natural and human systems. We showed that there has been no statistically significant slowdown, pause or hiatus in global warming during the 21st century. In addition, we showed that a portion of the observed regional increases in extreme heat can be explained by changes in the frequency of atmospheric circulation patterns; that daily-scale precipitation variability, extreme wet spell intensity, and extreme dry spell frequency have all increased during the Indian monsoon season; that long-term statewide warming has doubled the frequency of the co-occurring low-precipitation/high-temperature conditions that produce drought in California; and that the episodes of persistent atmospheric ridging that have caused low precipitation during California’s history have become more likely in recent decades. Together, these analyses have detected historical changes in the physical dynamics that create climate extremes. Further, by analyzing a broader suite of non-climatic observations, we have shown that extreme heat creates supply-side shocks that have contributed to historical U.S. corn price volatility; and that recent episodes of large Amazon carbon loss have been associated with extreme wet-season heat and extreme dry-season drought. These analyses of historical data illustrate the critical role of climate extremes in shaping biological and economic impacts.

• “Extreme event attribution”: We are developing a unified approach for testing whether historical global warming has increased the probability of extreme events that are unprecedented in the observed climate record. This approach is grounded on three pillars: (1) Understanding the physical causes of the extreme event; (2) Using formal uncertainty quantification to quantify the probability of those conditions in the current climate; and (3) Using formal hypothesis testing to compare that current probability with the probability in a climate without human influence. We have applied our analysis to a number of different climate extremes, including temperature, soil moisture, and atmospheric circulation patterns. Together, this work has shown that global warming can influence the risk of unprecedented extreme events by altering the probability of the physical conditions responsible for the event.

• Importance of physical climate dynamics for design and implementation of climate policy: Our work at the dynamics-impacts interface suggests that in order to be accurate, climate policy analyses must integrate more realistic climate dynamics. For example, we showed that increases in extreme heat alter the influence of biofuels mandates on corn price volatility, and that the price impacts of global warming are substantially greater if biofuels market integration is mandate-driven rather than market-driven. Further, contrary to arguments that the rate of carbon emissions is less important than the cumulative total, we showed that the increased velocity of climate change associated with faster rates of emissions substantially increases the risk to many terrestrial ecosystems. Taken together, these studies highlight the sensitivity of policy outcomes to the physical dynamics that shape high-impact climate change.
